headline: Defense ETFs Down as Lockheed Tumbles, Northrop Soars
summary: - Lockheed Martin Corp (LMT) dropped 8% Tuesday, while Northrop Grumman Corp (NOC) surged by the same amount. - The moves suggest that investors may be reassessing valuations and locking in profits.

headline: Defense sector earnings: How to play the sector
summary: Lockheed Martin (LMT) and Northrop Grumman (NOC) both announced second quarter results on Tuesday, but Lockheed is plummeting while Northrop surges. Seaport Research Partners senior analyst for aerospace and defense Richard Safran joins Market Domination with Josh Lipton to explain why he still sees upside for Lockheed, Boeing (BA), and others amid rising defense spending. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.

headline: Why Northrop Grumman Stock Is Up Today
summary: The company has a great long-term franchise, but investors should be careful chasing rallies in defense stocks.  Investors were pleased, sending Northrop shares up 8% as of 1 p.m. ET.  The beat included a $1.04-per-share gain from the sale of a subsidiary, but even backing out that sale, Northrop's $7.11-per-share profit was better than expected.

headline: Kohl's, Philip Morris, RTX & Northrop Grumman: Trending Tickers
summary: Kohl's (KSS) stock is skyrocketing, fueled by a larger meme stock rally in what may be a short squeeze. Philip Morris (PM) stock slumps after the company's second quarter sales numbers came in lower than analysts expected. The company also cut its full-year outlook for product shipments. Defense stocks are moving after RTX (RTX) and Northrop Grumman (NOC) topped expectations in their earnings results and updated their full-year outlooks. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts here.

headline: Stocks Little Changed as Earnings Pour In
summary: Stocks were mixed at the open on Tuesday as Wall Street sifted through the latest wave of earnings reports and looked ahead to the big names due out in the days and weeks to come.  The Nasdaq Composite was down 0.2%.  “You can’t fault investors for taking a step back to catch their breath as earnings season picks up and we approach the August 1st tariff deadlines,” writes Bespoke Investment Group co-founder Paul Hickey.

headline: Northrop Grumman’s (NYSE:NOC) Q2: Beats On Revenue
summary: Security and aerospace company Northrop Grumman (NYSE:NOC) reported Q2 CY2025 results exceeding the market’s revenue expectations, with sales up 1.3% year on year to $10.35 billion. The company expects the full year’s revenue to be around $42.15 billion, close to analysts’ estimates. Its GAAP profit of $8.15 per share was 18.9% above analysts’ consensus estimates.

headline: Northrop Grumman: Q2 Earnings Snapshot
summary: NOC) on Tuesday reported second-quarter earnings of $1.17 billion. On a per-share basis, the Falls Church, Virginia-based company said it had profit of $8.15. Earnings, adjusted for non-recurring gains, came to $7.11 per share.

headline: Northrop Grumman lifts 2025 profit forecast on strong demand for weapons
summary: (Reuters) -Northrop Grumman raised its annual profit forecast and topped Wall Street estimates for second-quarter revenue on Tuesday, aided by sustained demand for its military aircraft and defense systems as geopolitical tensions simmer.  A protracted Russia-Ukraine war and conflict in the Middle East have boosted demand for weapons from defense contractors such as Northrop.  The company, which makes the B-2 Spirit stealth bombers that were used in U.S. strikes on Iran's nuclear sites in June, is also expected to benefit from President Donald Trump's defense budget for next year that seeks more missiles and drones.

A protracted Russia-Ukraine war and conflict in the Middle East have boosted demand for weapons from defense contractors such as Northrop.  The company, which makes the B-2 Spirit stealth bombers that were used in U.S. strikes on Iran's nuclear sites in June, is also expected to benefit from President Donald Trump's defense budget for next year that seeks more missiles and drones.
